question: Outline the difference between accuracy and precision in analytical measurements.

sample_answer.full_answer: Accuracy refers to closeness to the true value, whereas precision refers to reproducibility of repeated measurements (2 marks).

question: Explain the purpose of control charts in routine analytical work.

sample_answer.full_answer: Control charts track QC sample results over time (1 mark), reveal trends or shifts that indicate instrument drift or bias (1 mark), and trigger corrective action when results exceed warning/action limits (1 mark).

marking_criteria.criteria: Mentions corrective action on limit exceedance.

common_mistakes: Describing calibration curves instead of control charts.

question: Replicate arsenic measurements (µg L^-1) give 12.3, 12.7, 12.5, 12.8, and 12.4. Calculate the sample mean, standard deviation, and percent relative standard deviation (%RSD).

sample_answer.full_answer: Mean = 12.54 µg L^-1 (1 mark). Standard deviation (n-1) = 0.18 µg L^-1 (1 mark). %RSD = (0.18 / 12.54) × 100 = 1.4% (2 marks).

marking_criteria.criteria: Calculates %RSD with correct units and significant figures.

common_mistakes: Dividing by n instead of n-1 or misplacing decimal.

question: Compare spike recovery and analysis of certified reference materials (CRM) as approaches to assess accuracy.

sample_answer.full_answer: Spike recovery tests the method in the sample matrix by adding known analyte, revealing matrix effects (2 marks). CRM analysis measures a sample with certified value to verify bias relative to traceable standards (2 marks).
common_mistakes: Calling CRM a spike or failing to mention certified value.

question: You must report mercury concentration with expanded uncertainty (k = 2). Describe a workflow for constructing an uncertainty budget and calculating the expanded uncertainty for a UV-Vis method that includes calibration slope uncertainty, instrumental noise, and sample preparation variability.

sample_answer.full_answer: 1) Identify sources: calibration slope (slope standard error), instrumental noise (σ_blank), and sample preparation (pipette tolerance, volumetric flask uncertainty) (2 marks). 2) Convert each to standard uncertainty (divide tolerances by √3 where appropriate, propagate through calculations) (2 marks). 3) Combine standard uncertainties by root-sum-of-squares to obtain combined standard uncertainty and multiply by coverage factor k = 2 for 95% confidence (2 marks).

marking_criteria.criteria: Explains conversion to standard uncertainty for each source.
Describes combination (RSS) and application of coverage factor.
